Under [[NEXTSTEP]], [[Mac OS X]] and [[GNUstep]], a '''bundle''' is a [[directory (file systems)|directory]] that allows related resources such as [[software]] [[object file|code]] to be grouped together. They were introduced into the [[Apple Macintosh|Macintosh]] world as ''packages'' in [[Mac OS 9]] and are similar in concept to the [[Application Directory|Application Directories]] used in [[RISC OS]], on the [[ROX Desktop]] and on [[Super OS]] ([[RUNZ]] bundles).
+
Under [[NEXTSTEP]], [[Mac OS X]] and [[GNUstep]], a '''bundle''' is a [[directory (file systems)|directory]] (or file) that allows related resources such as [[software]] [[object file|code]] to be grouped together. They were introduced into the [[Apple Macintosh|Macintosh]] world as ''packages'' in [[Mac OS 9]] and are similar in concept to the [[Application Directory|Application Directories]] used in [[RISC OS]], on the [[ROX Desktop]] and on [[Super OS]] ([[RUNZ]] bundles).
[[Application software|Applications]], [[Application framework|frameworks]], and [[plugin]]s are most commonly grouped as bundles, although documents can also be grouped as bundles. They are manipulated with the <tt>NSBundle</tt> class in the NeXT Foundation kit, and with <tt>CFBundle</tt> under [[Core Foundation]].
[[Application software|Applications]], [[Application framework|frameworks]], and [[plugin]]s are most commonly grouped as bundles, although documents can also be grouped as bundles. They are manipulated with the <tt>NSBundle</tt> class in the NeXT Foundation kit, and with <tt>CFBundle</tt> under [[Core Foundation]].
